description: From Middle English ofspring, from Old English ofspring (“offspring, descendants, posterity”), equivalent to off- +‎ spring. Compare Icelandic afspringur (“offspring”). More at off, spring.

entries.meaning: A person's daughter(s) and/or son(s); a person's children.
All of a person's descendants, including further generations.
An animal or plant's progeny or young.
(figuratively) Anything produced; the result of an entity's efforts.
examples: Artists often treasure their works as their immortal offspring.

entries.meaning: (computing) A process launched by another process.
